casebody.data:
UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee, v. Hector CUELI, Defendant-Appellant. No. 11-15293

Non-Argument Calendar.

United States Court of Appeals, Eleventh Circuit. Dec. 31, 2012. Susan Hollis Rothstein-Youakim, Robert E. O’Neill, Michelle Thresher Taylor, Maria Chapa Lopez, U.S. Attorney’s Office, Tampa, FL, for Plaintiff-Appellee. Daniel Lawrence Castillo, Stephen A. Leal, PA, Tampa, FL, for Defendant-Appellant. Before TJOFLAT, KRAVITCH, and EDMONDSON, Circuit Judges. *848PER CURIAM:

Hector Cueli appeals his conviction and sentence for manufacturing and possessing with the intent to distribute 100 or more marijuana plants: 21 U.S.C. § 841(a)(1) and (b)(i)(B)(vii).

Briefly stated, the case presents these issues:

(1) Whether the district court erred in denying Cueli’s motion to suppress evidence based on its finding that Cueli gave valid consent to detectives to enter his home; and
(2) Whether the district court erred in denying Cueli the benefit of the “safety valve” provision based on its finding that Cueli was not truthful during sentencing.

In the light of the record evidence (including Cueli’s own testimony), Cueli voluntarily consented to the search of his home. Therefore, the district court did not err in denying Cueli’s motion to suppress the evidence obtained from the search. The district court also did not err in denying Cueli safety-valve relief based on its finding that Cueli was not sufficiently truthful and complete — for example, about the involvement of others and about the plan for distribution — in providing information concerning his offense.

AFFIRMED.
